topic.title: Can the owner of ZeroTalk delete/modify any content here?
topic.body:
I'm mainly interested if there is any safeguard ensuring that nobody (not even the owner of the Zite) can delete/modify the topic or comment added by somebody else. 

If there is such a safeguard, please explain how does it work, and how can we check if a clone of this Zite also has that feature. 

If there is no such safeguard, is it possible/difficult to create a Zite having that feature?

topic.title: Why there is no search function on ZeroTalk?
ZeroBoard: Message submit failed! undefined [solved]
topic.body: Every time I try to submit something on [ZeroBoard](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Board.ZeroNetwork.bit/), I get the "Message submit failed! undefined" error message... :-(

topic.title: Can it be told beforehand if a magnet link points to a trustworthy software or not?
topic.body:
It would be nice to be able to tell before downloading the file if it corresponds to the unmodified or a compromised one. 

For example, [ZeroLinux](http://127.0.0.1:43110/zerolinux.bit/) contains a really nice collection of magnet links. The only thing I miss is some assurance that the if we download an iso file using those links we get the unmodified versions. 
  
Take for example the magnet link of Tails Linux 2.4:
magnet:?xt=urn:btih:e507dc3c0e30772fe561bbd78d627254495bd9be&dn=tails-i386-2.4
Is it possible to tell from the bittorrent info hash (btih) if it corresponds to the unmodified iso file? 

I'm wonder if there is a good way to extend the [ISRtalk](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15CmNF5L1murN3UMb4fZMuWJtpq689JRhx/) SHA256 and MD5 hash sum database to gain trust in magnet links, too.

topic.title: We should attract more people with web developing skills to ZeroNet.
topic.body:
ZeroNet is really awesome. I do hope it is the future.
I think in the current state what it needs most are more people who are capable (and willing) to create new Zites that worth to visit. 

Any ideas where from and how could we attract these kind of people here? 

I think the feature one can have webpages on ZeroNet without paying for a server could be quite attractive for some people... especially if we take it into account that Zites are also reachable from outside via [proxies](http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeroproxies.bit/).

topic.title: How Free (as in freedom) is your system?
topic.body: Run [vrms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vrms) and share your level of Freedom.

topic.title: Internal error: Exception: Merger site (ZeroMe) does not have permission for merged site: 1NFiNiTYxiKn5PJo9eDEsiusJJUFkew5Vo
topic.body:
What does that mean? How to overcome it?
The error message come up when I wanted to comment on a post on a profile I visited directly from ZeroMe.

topic.title: Let's collect here some legal (and semi-legal) hidden services
topic.body:
Please help me build here a collection of legal (and semi-legal) hidden services. 


_Legal hidden services:_
- DuckDuckGo: http://3g2upl4pq6kufc4m.onion/
- The Hidden Wiki:  http://zqktlwi4fecvo6ri.onion/wiki/index.php/Main_Page
- ProPublica (independent non-profit public interest newsroom):  http://www.propub3r6espa33w.onion
- Facebook: https://www.facebookcorewwwi.onion
- Onion services run by the Debian project: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp_6
- 

_Semi-legal hidden services:_
- Sci-Hub: http://scihub22266oqcxt.onion/
- 

I'm only interested in legal hidden services and semi-legal ones (that should be legal morally).

topic.title: [Question] Can a ZeroNet account be closed?
topic.body: If not, what is the closest thing that we can do if we would like to close an account?

> [sbeee](#comment_26_13k6itGVhzLTZUZKiqWWJ5KdvVUEMqDWDv): no peers found :/

Try again, I see 18 peers now.

@talk: Can you please add some white "quite zone" around the generated image symmetrically? 

It will make your QR Code Generator unquestionably better than the one we are already playing with in this [0Chan thread](http://127.0.0.1:43110/0chan.bit/?/b/thread/596e394df4bee5a8164942fa8a4b6b63).

14_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN.body:
> [zeroexef](#comment_6_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): The idea is that we verify the one on their site (by having several people download and hash the files), then ours are more reliable because we've distributed the result.

Okay, you got my attention.
Can you please explain it in more detail because I'm not sure I get it, but I'm interested.

> [zeroexef](#comment_7_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): It's not foolproof, but if have a bunch of people download the software (pref. from different countries, areas, whatever), and we take the most common version across the world (everybody rums an md5sum, we discard anything that doesn't match the majority), then we can 'ensure' the software is genuine. This way if anybody tried to modify the original website (and md5sum posted there) in any single country/area (e.g. MITM), we would be able to show that that version isn't the same as the one everybody else has.

Count me in. 

I can contribute with the following: if you provide me a list of Download links, I can automatically Download all the files and generate the a list of SHA1 and MD5 sums. As a proof of concept, I have generated this list: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp_0

> [zeroexef](#comment_13_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): http://127.0.0.1:43110/15CmNF5L1murN3UMb4fZMuWJtpq689JRhx

To encourage and help people to contribute to the database, here is a simple Bash script that auto generates all the important info (file name, timestamp, source, sha256 and md5 sums) from a download link (they just have to copy-paste the outcome in the corresponding topic): [0isrsum.sh](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp_2)

> [zeroexef](#comment_17_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): So I got the optional files up and running. If you can spare ~600MB it would be a huge help if you all could go to the site enable all optional files.
> 
> Just drag the 0 in the top right corner to get to page settings, then scroll down and enable "Download and help distribute all files"

It took two days to download, but now finally I have and seed them all... =)

I have improved the data generating script. Now [0isrsum.sh](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp_3) works with both links pointing to files and with files that are already downloaded.

3_1CoVAt2jBzV4Na6nX3VG1JSfjS8fwse1Z9.body:
If this is a bait, it is a good one.

But if you are serious, then I think you are the one missing the point of ZeroNet. 

The following is from http://zeronet.io/:
> We believe in
> open, free, and uncensored
> network and communication.
The word "uncensored" is literally in their slogan. So banning politics from ZeroNet is a ridiculous idea. 
Of course, banning it from certain Zites (especially from your Zite) is a different thing. 

By the way, I also hate politics. However, there are times when we should not stick our heads in the sand. So I would not even agree with you if you were only arguing for banning politics completely from ZeroTalk.  

Nevertheless, I agree with you in that it matters a lot what kind of content we fill the first Zites. And that depends only on us, but I don't mind that the main powers we have here against trolls is ignoring them and not joining them. 

Final thoughts: It is worthless asking trolls to behave nicely. It is better asking the others to ignore them and to fill ZeroNet with quality content instead.

1_1HMgJTFYY57XoH9wpBJHQZsWPvwsRp1WHX.body:
@decentrius: Nice idea. 
Let's build a Church of Emacs on ZeroNet.

@decentrius: Don't get me wrong, but I think as the founder/leader of the first Church of Emacs on ZeroNet you should be a bit more active both in interacting with people in the church and in encouraging folks to join the church visiting it actively and regularly.

Yesterday, I wanted to start a "confession topic" for confessing sins of using proprietary software in the church and also to start a tread on [0chan](http://127.0.0.1:43110/0chan.bit/?/b/) to evangelize the lost folks there, but I have no idea what kind of activity you would like to have in the church and it is hard to guess without your active presence. I would like to combine the serious discussion about free software and having some fun in your church but not without your consent.  

So pleas lead and give us some directions, but at least tell us how we should behave in your church. A [sticked post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:2_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf) in the church with some general guidance would also be nice. 

What do you think?

4_19sggoAZ4hcorrrfWoFWP9rwfpVsL29cnZ.body:
Sineryc is right there are several Zites for torrent sharing on ZeroNet, but they are not good enough. 

[Play](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1PLAYgDQboKojowD3kwdb3CtWmWaokXvfp/) is only for movies and it lacks the possibility of user contribution. 

[TV episodes](http://127.0.0.1:43110/tvepisodes.bit/) is only for series, it lacks lacks the possibility of user contribution and a good search function. 

[ZeroTorrent](http://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroTorrent.bit/) has the possibility of user contribution and a search function, but it is clumsy. It is quite clear that it was cloned from a Zite that was designed for something else. It also lacks some automatic generation of magnet links like that of [TV episodes](http://127.0.0.1:43110/tvepisodes.bit/). 

So I agree: it would be really cool if someone designed a Zite for torrent sharing that has all the good features but not the bad ones of the already existing Zites.

1_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp.body:
> [nofish](#comment_705_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): The site owner able to modify any content on his/her site: Edit the user's json file from data dir, then sign/publish it using the sidebar with the site's privatekey.

I don't know if that is a bad or a good feature in general, but there are certain situations where it would be quite important to have a safeguard like that.  

For example, in the [Zero ISR](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12oGb8xBjLYz23CGJxRQyzZ6mGybZokEKt/) software repository the sha256 and md5 sums are considered trustworthy based on the [ISRtalk](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15CmNF5L1murN3UMb4fZMuWJtpq689JRhx/) community collected sha256 and md5 sum database. 

The lack of this safeguard (ensuring that the comments are not manipulated) seems to be a security risk in these kind of projects where something becomes trustworthy if plenty of independent users have the same results. 

So I think my second question is still interesting and important: 
_Is it possible to create a Zite having a safeguard ensuring that the comments have not been modified by some one else (not even by the owner of the Zite)?_

@tkarita: I don't quite see yet how can it be used to make the [ISRtalk](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15CmNF5L1murN3UMb4fZMuWJtpq689JRhx/) hash repository more secure, but thanx for the interesting info anyway.

3_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp.body:
I'm on a GNU/Linux using Firefox 47.0. 
Yes, I have rebooted my computer recently. My uptime is only 16 days =) 
This is a persistent error. I got it several times in the past couple of months. 
The only difference is that now I thought I mention it here. 
Maybe others have the same issue and someone knows how to solve it.

It was add-on related my [uMatrix](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/umatrix/) was blocking XHR from site demo.zeronet.io. Whitelisting XHR from demo.zeronet.io on uMatrix solved the message submission problem.

Reading [protect yourselves: set a non-working proxy](http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeroblog.bit/?Post:60:protect+yourselves:+set+a+non-working+proxy) on Erkan's blog helped me lot finding the root of my message submitting problem. I do recommend reading that blog post especially if you prefer not sending your data/info through the clearnet. 
 
Related to this subject it also worth quoting "ZeroBoard sends your data (IP, ...) into normal internet" from http://127.0.0.1:43110/zerosecurity.bit.

8_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh.body:
On a regular basis: only Tor and Tox,
but I have also tried YaCy, BitMessage, Ring, and IPFS.

Edit: Yes, I also use Syncthing... I don't know why I have forgotten it.

> [kensan](#comment_38_1LUP6SN7WrXAH7e5bUFxdmrVsFr2m43XB4): Diaspora*?

Diaspora* is not P2P but it is a nice Decentralized/Federated project. 
I was not listing it because I was not sure if it counts here. 
I think it should count but it depend what @kaffie meant by "P2P/Decentralized".

> [kaffie](#comment_120_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): I wasn't really aiming for stuff like diaspora. More of software you run on your local machine to connect to a larger network of peers to achieve something. I mean, it's fine. More for the list, but not really what I was after.

So my hesitation was right... By the way, people can run their own Diaspora* pods to connect the network. So I still think it is sort of a borderline case...

> [kensan](#comment_41_1LUP6SN7WrXAH7e5bUFxdmrVsFr2m43XB4): It is like Facebook but decentralized.

@kensan: I know you meant well and sorry for my comment, but for me saying "Diaspora* is like Facebook" is similar to saying "Heaven is like Hell"... you know some religious people think we go one of those places after death... yes maybe Heaven is a bit less crowded... but no real difference ;-)

Yes, [Diaspora*](https://diasporafoundation.org/) is also a social network, but
- it respects your freedom and privacy
- it does not spies on you
- it does not poisons your mind with ads
- it does not create a [filter bubble](http://www.ted.com/talks/eli_pariser_beware_online_filter_bubbles?language=en) around you
- you can trust it (you can inspect/modify/redistribute the source code and you can host your own pod)
- etc.

So, _no_, Diaspora* is not like Facebook at all.

> [kensan](#comment_44_1LUP6SN7WrXAH7e5bUFxdmrVsFr2m43XB4): Yes I agree, but if you know nothing about D*, i can tell you that ;)
> It is "my" pod:https://diasp.eu

It's okay. I just could not resit. It just felt so good expressing how much better D* is than fb. =)

24_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP.body:
Chess is a good idea, but something simpler like Five in a Row would also be good.

I would prefer some simple games that can be played by several users together (the more the merrier).

There is a Reversi game on Zite [AlertChat](http://127.0.0.1:43110/164KTePHASdAB4o24XEZw1peQtwyjmFQxF/), but currently it is way too complicated to play. It needs some redesign, but I think it can be a basis of a simple but good board game on ZeroNet.    

Can someone from here improve it?

Join the conversation even if you have no need idea how to improve the game but you have the web developing skills and capacity to do that. Probably, the rest of ZeroNet community will be able to provide you the required ideas, see for example the recent discussion on http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeromedia.bit/.

8_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp.body:
> [ancap](#comment_77_1FYXQGLBeNabf5jZHgP4CwzbmJSKaK4oMz): Then you're (legally) in trouble because illegal but lawful sites could get you in trouble. 

I'm not sure...  For example,  there are plenty of countries where downloading copyrighted material from the internet is not illegal (only uploading them is illegal)...  but that is beside of the point now.

Moreover, Sci-Hub is quite harmless because open access is clearly the future of scientific and educational publications...

> Also I don't see a point in bookmark sharing. There are search sites for Tor and they work quite well. Besides Tor sites frequently come and go and information collected this way gets stale quickly.

My main motivation of collecting a list of legal hidden services is disproving the general belief that only criminals sites have hidden services... probably there are other benefits of having such a list. For example, I learn about onion sites from lists and not by using hidden search engines, but I'm a pretty causal user of the Tor network... 

Please, suggest good hidden search engines for this list.   
 
> And last but not least we don't know you and you don't know us, so it's rather stupid for you to click on links you get from us, and vice versa. 

Why? I see no danger clicking a link (using torbrowser while the script blocker is on)...  Hanging around in ZeroNet is more dangerous, I guess... 

> Better contribute to some Tor directory project or maybe start one which does proper curation and organization on ZeroNet.

If you know an already existing such ZeroNet project, then please tell me. 
If you think there is no such projects, please suggest me better ways to start one than this ZeroTalk thread.

3_17vKbxL13KnzGATstqawXSG2oiQygmdkcX.body:
I have tried to recover the deleted files with ```testdisk```, but all of them is empty?! 
It seems like it was a more systematic data wipe than a simple delete. 

However, some Zeronet user with more a advanced file recovery skill may still be able to recover the deleted data from the remains on his/her drive. 

So if you had the data and have the skills (or a friend with the skills), please recover it and share the recovered data. Someone may be able to use it to rebuild ZeroTv.
